perturbation.original_text: Subject to sub-clause below, each Party shall treat as strictly confidential all information received or obtained as a result of entering into or performing this Agreement. Each Party may disclose information which would otherwise be confidential if and to the extent:   (i) required by the law of any relevant jurisdiction; (ii) the information has come into the public domain through no fault of that Party; or (iii) the other Party has given prior written approval to the disclosure, provided that any such information disclosed shall be disclosed only after consultation with and notice to the other Party.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party shall treat as strictly confidential all information received or obtained as a result of entering into or performing this Agreement. Each Party may disclose information which would otherwise be confidential if and to the extent:  (i) required by the law of any relevant jurisdiction.
perturbation.explanation: By omitting clauses (ii) and (iii) concerning information entering the public domain and prior written approval, the modified text contradicts the potential for legitimate disclosures under the original agreement. It creates uncertainty regarding acceptable disclosure practices, particularly if a party inadvertently or legitimately discloses confidential information that later becomes public knowledge, or when HPIL ET has given prior written approval to the disclosure. The remaining text states that both parties should consider all info as strictly confidential, but then allows disclosure if the law requires it. It implies that those are the only conditions. Omitting (ii) and (iii) creates a contradiction that would make the agreement unenforceable.
